Dating: ROMAN PERIOD (not before); BYZANTINE PERIOD ?; BYZANTINE PERIOD (not after)
Technique: FORMED ON THE POTTER'S WHEEL; PAINTED; ENGRAVED
Name: Hollow dish with an inverted rim
Description: This hollow dish in terracotta, which was acquired in the art trade of Cairo, is a beautiful example of an egyptian imitation of roman crockery. The inside base is decorated by a motif of intersected lines which have been applied during the turning with the help of a "vibrating knife". The dish, which is characterised also by an inverted rim, dates from the end of the Roman Period.
